thread.title: Wheat Kings rally to beat Americans
thread.title_full: Wheat Kings rally to beat Americans

title: Wheat Kings rally to beat Americans
text:
Wheat Kings rally to beat Americans By: Perry Bergson Report Error 
The Brandon Wheat Kings came from behind for the second game in a row to beat the Tri-City Americans 5-3 at the Toyota Center in Kennewick, Wash., on Friday. On the second night of a five-game swing through the Western Hockey League’s U.S. Division, the Wheat Kings (8-1-0-2) overcame a 2-1 deficit midway through the second, scoring twice in the last seven minutes of the second period and twice more in the final five minutes of the third period to improve to 5-0 on the road this season. 
Wheat Kings head coach and general manager Kelly McCrimmon was happy with his team. 
"I liked our game tonight," McCrimmon said. "I thought we played well. We withstood a few challenges with the penalties that we took in the second. … There were a lot of good things for our team on the road tonight." 
The Wheat Kings took an early lead when 16-year-old Stelio Mattheos scored his second of the year, a lead erased just over two minutes later by Tri-City’s Tyler Sandhu. 
The Americans took a 2-1 lead on a four-on-four goal by Parker Bowles. It came midway through the second during a stretch in which the Wheat Kings took four penalties in seven minutes. 
But a John Quenneville short-handed goal and Rihards Bukarts’ power-play marker put Brandon up 3-2 before the period ended. 
Tri-City tied the game 12:21 into the third on a goal by Juuso Valimaki off a nice feed from Strathclair’s Morgan Geekie, but it didn’t last long. 
Bukarts scored his second of the game two minutes later and Jayce Hawryluk managed to score a bad-angle empty-netter to seal the win with 25 seconds left. 
Mattheos said it was a solid victory for the Wheat Kings. 
"It was a pretty big battle out there," Mattheos said. "We rallied late and got the win. It was a good win for us on the road." 
McCrimmon was pleased with the offensive contributions from throughout the lineup, with nine different players hitting on the scoresheet. 
After a 4-3 shootout victory over the Spokane Chiefs on Wednesday and Friday’s win in Kennewick, the Wheat Kings have twice been confronted by teams that make it difficult to get shots to the net. 
"That’s been the case through two nights," McCrimmon said. "They play a little bit of a different style than the teams in the East but that could change as we go along." 
The Wheat Kings next see action on Sunday against the Portland Winterhawks (3-6-0-0), who sit last in the U.S. Division. 
ICINGS: Brandon scratched a pair of new additions to the team’s sick bay, F Reid Duke (lower body) and F Linden McCorrister (upper body), along with two forwards who didn’t make the West Coast trip, Tim McGauley and Ty Lewis (upper-body injuries, out week-to-week) Both Duke and McCorrister are day to day and could skate on Sunday … D Mark Matsuba played forward for the Wheat Kings on Friday, a role he was also asked to fill last spring in the playoffs. 
» pbergson@brandonsun.com
